docs.lead_paragraph: SO far, it's Taxpayers v. Merchants of Death. Eight states have sued tobacco companies, and more are getting in line, with a new legal theory: since the states incur Medicaid expenses for smoking-related illness, they should be reimbursed by the industry that causes it. There's a snag, though. The states are probably not losing all the money they are asking for. The inconvenient truth, at least as many economists see it, is that smokers cover their own medical costs, not only by paying cigarette taxes -- now more than 50 cents a pack -- but also by dying before collecting their full share of health and retirement benefits.

headline.main: Tobacco on Trial;Making a Case for Death

docs.lead_paragraph: A new Democratic Party television commercial takes a not-too-subtle swipe at Senator Bob Dole, age 72. After a shot of him side-by-side with Speaker Newt Gingrich, the announcer warns (emphasis added): "Their old ways don't work. President Clinton's plan -- the new way." Jack Quinn, the White House counsel, pointedly describes a recent Dole speech as "tired, old, worn-out rhetoric."

headline.main: Still Running;Is Age-Bashing Any Way to Beat Bob Dole?

docs.lead_paragraph: GRACE HAS MACE," a 30-minute, black-and-white film, was born five years ago on a creepy-dark midtown street. The director/ waitress, Julianne Berg, and the actor/bartender, Patrick Inzetta, were walking back downtown one summer night from their jobs at the old Lone Star Roadhouse uptown. To keep up their courage, they imagined a superhero to save them from the muggers they imagined in the shadows. It would be a woman. Her name would be Grace. One of them laughed and said, "Grace has Mace." The phrase kept rolling around in Ms. Berg's head, while she was waitressing, interning at a TV production house, working two video editing jobs to help support her recently divorced mother, teaching herself the limits of a Super 8 camera, flipping the bird at guys who harassed her on the street. When Ms. Berg, a willowy 29-year-old who resembles the actress Juliette Lewis, is feeling particularly cranky, she just laughs at the guys on the street.

headline.main: On Friends, Cult Classics and Small Budgets

docs.lead_paragraph: ROY G. GERONEMUS, M.D., specializes in wiping away youthful indiscretions, drunken follies, lost loves. Dr. Geronemus is not a psychotherapist. He is a tattoo remover.

docs.lead_paragraph: Freed of all legislative burdens until Tuesday, the Senate today devoted the first day of its four-day weekend to politics -- and history. On a more or less contemporary note, Senator Bob Dole attacked President Clinton over the 4.3-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax increase that was enacted in 1993 despite unanimous Republican opposition. Seizing on the recent rise in gasoline prices, Mr. Dole said, "Americans are overtaxed and need relief."

headline.main: Senators Parry on Gasoline Tax and Wages

docs.lead_paragraph: My first impressions of mental illness were probably the same as most other children of my generation. It was something shameful, forbidden, never to be discussed. Home alone on a Sunday afternoon some 30-odd years ago, I answered the phone to discover that a relative I hadn't met was calling collect. I had been instructed never to accept collect calls, and as I turned this caller away, she screamed over the operator's voice: "They're killing everyone in Baltimore!" Then the phone went dead, and only years later, as this woman neared death, would my parents put her illness and her subsequent, similarly terrifying calls into the comprehensible perspective of a diagnosed sickness with a treatment -- and, today, possibly a cure. We're all much more sophisticated now, of course. You can't look at the TV or best-seller list without encountering an avuncular shrink. But sometimes you wonder how universal the country's understanding of mental illness really is. For three years Vincent Foster's suicidal depression has been a political football, as if it could be explained by some obvious, single motive rather than as the product of a sick man's complex pathology. Only last week did Margot Kidder's public breakdown become a cue for headlines and voyeurism that a grave physical illness would never have warranted.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Pataki administration today threatened to allow the state's system of setting hospital rates to expire on July 1, potentially throwing the health care industry into chaos, if the Legislature does not agree to deregulate the industry by then. Health care officials said that the move would force many hospitals, particularly those serving poor communities, to roll back vital services or even close by the end of the year.

headline.main: Pataki Issues An Ultimatum On Hospitals
